content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends the Communications Act of 1934 by adding a new section that revises duopoly rules. The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" amends the Communications Act of 1934 by revising duopoly rules. The Act limits the Commission from prohibiting ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market, with one being a UHF station. It also protects existing local marketing agreements between broadcast television stations in the same market. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act exempts marketing or time brokerage agreements between two broadcast television stations in the same market from the television duopoly rule. The Commission can allow ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market under certain circumstances. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act exempts ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market under certain conditions, ensuring it does not harm competition or media diversity. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission will modify regulations to eliminate restrictions on granting or renewing broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and remove the one-to-a-market rule. The Commission will not consider a minority voting stock interest as cognizable if one holder owns over 50% of the voting stock. Amendments to the Communications Act of 1934 include cable cross-ownership limitations. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to allow ownership of broadcasting stations and cable systems in the same community. SEC. 4 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 is amended to increase the ownership limit to 45 percent. The Federal Communications Commission must implement this change within 90 days. SEC. 5 addresses reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions. Subsection (b) of section 310 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses. No licenses shall be granted to aliens, foreign corporations, or corporations with more than one-fifth ownership by aliens. The Commission may allow foreign entities to own a portion of the capital stock of a corporation holding a broadcast station license in the US, based on reciprocity with the ownership rules of the foreign country. The Commission may permit ownership of capital stock in a corporation holding a broadcast station license in the US by individuals, corporations, or governments from the United States, with voting stock not exceeding 40 percent. The term 'United States person' includes corporations organized under US laws, US citizen individuals, and US government entities. The Commission allows ownership of capital stock in a corporation holding a broadcast station license in the US by US citizens, US government entities, or representatives of these individuals or entities.
